short_summary: Diwali celebrates the victory of light over darkness and good over evil.
description:
Diwali, also known as Deepavali, is one of the most important festivals in India. It symbolizes the triumph of light over darkness and righteousness over evil. Homes are cleaned and decorated with lamps and rangoli to welcome prosperity. The lighting of diyas represents hope, knowledge, and positivity.

Different regions celebrate Diwali with unique traditions. In North India, it marks Lord Rama’s return to Ayodhya. In Western India, it is associated with wealth and new beginnings. In Eastern India, Kali Puja is observed, while in Southern India it commemorates Lord Krishna’s victory over Narakasura.

Diwali is celebrated by Hindus, Jains, Sikhs, and Buddhists, each associating the festival with important historical or spiritual events. Sharing sweets, lighting lamps, and spending time with family are central to the celebration.

short_summary: Holi celebrates love, joy, and the arrival of spring through colors.
description:
Holi is a vibrant festival known for its celebration with colors. It marks the arrival of spring and the victory of good over evil, symbolized by the legend of Prahlada and Holika. People gather to throw colored powders, sing, dance, and share happiness.

The night before Holi, Holika Dahan is performed by lighting a bonfire to represent the burning of evil. The next day is filled with joyful color play and community bonding.

Holi promotes unity, forgiveness, and equality, as people forget differences and celebrate together.

short_summary: Navaratri honors the divine feminine through nine nights of worship.
description:
Navaratri is a nine-night festival dedicated to Goddess Durga and her various forms. Each day represents a different aspect of the goddess, symbolizing strength, wisdom, and protection.

In Eastern India, it culminates in Durga Puja. In Western India, people celebrate with Garba and Dandiya dances. In Southern India, homes display Golu dolls depicting mythological scenes.

The festival emphasizes devotion, discipline, and cultural unity.

short_summary: Ganesh Chaturthi celebrates the birth of Lord Ganesha.
description:
Ganesh Chaturthi marks the birth of Lord Ganesha, the remover of obstacles. Clay idols of Ganesha are installed in homes and public spaces, followed by prayers and celebrations.

The festival ends with Visarjan, where idols are immersed in water, symbolizing the cycle of creation and dissolution.

The festival promotes wisdom, humility, and devotion.

short_summary: Janmashtami celebrates the birth of Lord Krishna.
description:
Janmashtami marks the birth of Lord Krishna, celebrated with fasting, prayers, and devotional songs. Temples are decorated and scenes from Krishna’s life are reenacted.

At midnight, the time believed to be Krishna’s birth, special prayers are offered.

The festival teaches love, righteousness, and devotion.

short_summary: Maha Shivaratri honors Lord Shiva through night-long devotion.
description:
Maha Shivaratri is dedicated to Lord Shiva and observed with fasting and meditation. Devotees stay awake all night, offering prayers and chanting hymns.

The festival symbolizes self-control, inner awakening, and spiritual growth.

short_summary: Ram Navami celebrates the birth of Lord Rama.
description:
Ram Navami marks the birth of Lord Rama, symbolizing righteousness and moral values. Devotees read the Ramayana and participate in temple celebrations.

The festival emphasizes truth, duty, and compassion.

short_summary: Makar Sankranti marks the harvest season and sun’s transition.
description:
Makar Sankranti celebrates the sun’s movement into Capricorn and the harvest season. It is observed with gratitude to nature and farmers.

Different regions celebrate it with unique names and customs.

short_summary: Kumbh Mela is a major spiritual gathering for purification.
description:
Kumbh Mela is a massive pilgrimage where devotees bathe in sacred rivers. It is believed to cleanse sins and promote spiritual renewal.

It represents faith, devotion, and unity.

short_summary: Raksha Bandhan celebrates the bond between siblings.
description:
Raksha Bandhan symbolizes the love and protection between brothers and sisters. Sisters tie a rakhi on their brother’s wrist, and brothers promise protection.

The festival promotes family bonding and responsibility.

short_summary: Baisakhi celebrates the harvest season and the foundation of the Khalsa.
description:
Baisakhi is a major harvest festival celebrated primarily in Punjab. It marks the beginning of the new harvest season and holds deep religious importance for Sikhs.

On this day in 1699, Guru Gobind Singh Ji founded the Khalsa Panth, giving Baisakhi a strong spiritual significance. Devotees visit gurdwaras, participate in prayers, and engage in community service.

The festival reflects gratitude, courage, equality, and collective identity.

short_summary: Guru Nanak Jayanti celebrates the birth of Guru Nanak Dev Ji.
description:
Guru Nanak Jayanti commemorates the birth of Guru Nanak Dev Ji, the founder of Sikhism. The festival emphasizes teachings of equality, humility, and devotion to one God.

Celebrations include early morning prayers, processions, and devotional singing. Gurdwaras are beautifully decorated and langar is served to all.

The festival promotes unity, compassion, and service to humanity.

short_summary: Maghi and Lohri celebrate harvest, warmth, and seasonal change.
description:
Lohri marks the end of winter and is celebrated with bonfires, songs, and dances. It represents gratitude for the harvest and hope for prosperity.

Maghi follows Lohri and holds religious importance for Sikhs, commemorating historical sacrifices. Devotees visit gurdwaras and take holy dips.

Together, the festivals symbolize renewal, courage, and togetherness.

short_summary: Hola Mohalla showcases Sikh martial traditions and bravery.
description:
Hola Mohalla was established by Guru Gobind Singh Ji as a day for demonstrating strength, discipline, and martial skills. It is celebrated a day after Holi.

The festival features mock battles, weapon displays, poetry, and community service.

It highlights courage, unity, and preparedness.

short_summary: Paryushan focuses on self-reflection and forgiveness.
description:
Paryushan is the most important Jain festival, emphasizing self-discipline, fasting, and spiritual purification.

Devotees practice meditation, study scriptures, and seek forgiveness through the practice of forgiveness day.

The festival teaches non-violence, humility, and inner growth.

short_summary: Mahavir Jayanti celebrates the birth of Lord Mahavira.
description:
Mahavir Jayanti commemorates the birth of Lord Mahavira, the 24th Tirthankara of Jainism.

The festival emphasizes non-violence, truth, and self-discipline. Processions and prayers are common.

It inspires peaceful living and moral conduct.

short_summary: Mahamastakabhisheka is a grand Jain anointing ceremony.
description:
Mahamastakabhisheka is a rare Jain festival held at Shravanabelagola, honoring the statue of Gommateshwara Bahubali.

The ceremony involves pouring sacred substances over the statue, symbolizing humility and renunciation.

It reflects spiritual purity and detachment.

short_summary: Bhai Dooj celebrates the bond between brothers and sisters.
description:
Bhai Dooj marks the loving relationship between siblings. Sisters pray for their brothers’ well-being, and brothers promise protection.

The festival strengthens family bonds and mutual respect.

short_summary: Jnan Panchami celebrates knowledge and sacred texts.
description:
Jnan Panchami is a Jain festival dedicated to the preservation and worship of knowledge.

Holy scriptures are cleaned, restored, and revered, emphasizing learning and wisdom.

The festival promotes education and respect for knowledge.

short_summary: Kartik Poornima marks spiritual illumination and devotion.
description:
Kartik Poornima is observed on the full moon day of the Kartik month. It is associated with sacred river bathing and lamp offerings.

In some regions, it is celebrated as Dev Deepawali, where rivers and temples are illuminated.

The festival symbolizes purity, devotion, and enlightenment.

short_summary: Maun Ekadashi is observed through silence, fasting, and self-discipline.
description:
Maun Ekadashi is a Hindu observance dedicated to spiritual restraint and inner purification. Devotees observe silence (maun), fast, and engage in prayer and meditation.

The practice of silence is believed to help control the mind and senses, leading to spiritual clarity.

The festival emphasizes self-control, reflection, and devotion.

short_summary: Buddhist New Year marks renewal and spiritual reflection.
description:
Buddhist New Year is celebrated in many Buddhist communities to mark the beginning of a new year. It is a time for cleansing, renewal, and merit-making.

Devotees visit monasteries, offer prayers, and perform acts of kindness.

The festival encourages compassion, mindfulness, and ethical living.

short_summary: Magha Puja Day honors the Buddhist monastic community.
description:
Magha Puja Day commemorates an important gathering of Buddha’s disciples. It highlights the principles of moral discipline and spiritual wisdom.

Devotees participate in candle processions and meditation.

The festival promotes ethical conduct and harmony.

short_summary: Asalha Puja Day marks Buddha’s first sermon.
description:
Asalha Puja Day commemorates the first sermon delivered by Gautama Buddha after enlightenment.

It marks the beginning of the Buddhist monastic order and the teaching of the Eightfold Path.

The festival emphasizes wisdom and right conduct.

short_summary: Songkran celebrates renewal with water rituals.
description:
Songkran marks the traditional New Year in Thailand and neighboring regions. Water is used symbolically to wash away misfortune and welcome a fresh start.

People visit temples, honor elders, and participate in joyful water celebrations.

The festival represents purification, respect, and renewal.

short_summary: Gahambars celebrate creation and community sharing.
description:
Gahambars are six seasonal festivals observed in Zoroastrianism to honor different aspects of creation.

They emphasize gratitude, charity, and communal harmony through shared meals.

The festivals promote balance between humans and nature.

short_summary: Nouruz celebrates the Persian New Year and renewal.
description:
Nouruz marks the beginning of spring and the Persian New Year. It symbolizes renewal, hope, and balance.

Homes are cleaned and special tables are set with symbolic items.

The festival promotes harmony, gratitude, and new beginnings.

short_summary: Khordad Sal celebrates the birth of Prophet Zarathustra.
description:
Khordad Sal commemorates the birth of Prophet Zarathustra, the founder of Zoroastrianism.

Devotees visit fire temples and perform prayers.

The festival emphasizes truth, purity, and righteousness.

short_summary: Christmas celebrates the birth of Jesus Christ.
description:
Christmas commemorates the birth of Jesus Christ and is celebrated with joy and generosity.

Homes and churches are decorated, carols are sung, and gifts are exchanged.

The festival promotes love, peace, and kindness.

short_summary: Easter and Good Friday commemorate sacrifice and resurrection.
description:
Good Friday marks the crucifixion of Jesus Christ, symbolizing sacrifice and compassion. Easter celebrates his resurrection, representing hope and renewal.

Together, they form the most significant events in the Christian calendar.

The festivals emphasize faith, forgiveness, and new life.

short_summary: Easter celebrates the resurrection of Jesus Christ.
description:
Easter is the most important festival in Christianity, commemorating the resurrection of Jesus Christ after his crucifixion. It represents victory over death and the promise of new life.

The festival follows Good Friday and is observed with church services, prayers, and joyful celebrations. In many regions, Easter is associated with hope, renewal, and faith.

short_summary: Ramzan is a month of fasting, prayer, and reflection in Islam.
description:
Ramzan is the ninth month of the Islamic calendar and is observed by Muslims worldwide through fasting from dawn to sunset. The fast commemorates the revelation of the Holy Quran to Prophet Muhammad.

The month emphasizes self-discipline, charity, compassion, and spiritual growth.

short_summary: Muharram marks the Islamic New Year and a period of remembrance.
description:
Muharram is the first month of the Islamic calendar and is especially significant for remembering the martyrdom of Imam Husayn at the Battle of Karbala.

For many Muslims, it is a time of mourning, reflection, and prayer.

short_summary: Eid-e-Milad celebrates the birth of Prophet Muhammad.
description:
Eid-e-Milad commemorates the birth of Prophet Muhammad. Devotees remember his teachings of compassion, humility, and peace.

Mosques and homes are decorated, prayers are offered, and charitable acts are encouraged.

short_summary: Bakr-Id honors sacrifice and obedience to God.
description:
Bakr-Id commemorates Prophet Ibrahim’s devotion and willingness to sacrifice his son in obedience to God. It symbolizes faith, sacrifice, and generosity.

Animals are sacrificed, and the meat is shared with family, friends, and the needy.

short_summary: Rosh Hashanah marks the Jewish New Year.
description:
Rosh Hashanah is the Jewish New Year and a time for reflection and repentance. It marks the beginning of the High Holy Days in Judaism.

Devotees attend synagogue services and pray for a good and meaningful year ahead.

short_summary: Yom Kippur is the holiest day of Judaism focused on atonement.
description:
Yom Kippur is a solemn day dedicated to repentance and forgiveness. It is marked by fasting, prayer, and self-reflection.

Devotees seek forgiveness from God and from one another.

short_summary: Hanukkah celebrates faith and perseverance.
description:
Hanukkah commemorates the rededication of the Second Temple in Jerusalem. The festival is observed for eight nights by lighting the menorah.

It symbolizes hope, faith, and the triumph of light over darkness.

short_summary: Ugadi marks the New Year in parts of South India.
description:
Ugadi is celebrated as the New Year by Telugu and Kannada communities. It symbolizes new beginnings and hope.

People clean their homes, wear new clothes, and prepare traditional dishes representing different emotions of life.

short_summary: Lumbini Festival celebrates Buddhist heritage.
description:
The Lumbini Festival is a Buddhist cultural festival organized to promote peace and the teachings of Lord Buddha.

It includes prayers, cultural programs, and exhibitions reflecting Buddhist traditions.

short_summary: Tirupati Brahmotsavam is a grand temple festival dedicated to Lord Venkateswara.
description:
Tirupati Brahmotsavam is the most important festival celebrated at the Tirumala Venkateswara Temple. It spans several days and involves elaborate processions of the deity on different vahanas.

Devotees from across the country visit the temple during this period to seek blessings. The festival reflects devotion, discipline, and spiritual grandeur.

short_summary: Deccan Festival celebrates the cultural heritage of the Deccan region.
description:
The Deccan Festival is a cultural event showcasing the art, crafts, cuisine, and traditions of the Deccan plateau.

It includes music, dance, exhibitions, and food fairs, promoting regional unity and heritage.

short_summary: Siang River Festival promotes harmony and eco-cultural awareness.
description:
The Siang River Festival is celebrated in Arunachal Pradesh to promote unity among communities and awareness about nature.

It features river sports, traditional dances, and cultural exchanges.

short_summary: Pangsau Pass Winter Festival celebrates cross-border cultural ties.
description:
The Pangsau Pass Winter Festival is held near the historic Pangsau Pass in Arunachal Pradesh. It celebrates cultural connections between India and neighboring regions.

The festival features tribal dances, traditional sports, and exhibitions.

short_summary: Solung Festival is an agricultural festival of the Adi tribe.
description:
Solung is an important agricultural festival celebrated by the Adi tribe of Arunachal Pradesh. It marks sowing and harvesting activities.

The festival includes rituals, prayers, and community celebrations for prosperity.

short_summary: Losar marks the Tibetan New Year.
description:
Losar is celebrated as the Tibetan New Year by Buddhist communities. It marks the beginning of a new year with prayers and festive gatherings.

The festival symbolizes renewal, purification, and good fortune.

short_summary: Rongali Bihu marks the Assamese New Year and spring.
description:
Rongali Bihu is the most important Bihu festival of Assam, celebrating the Assamese New Year and the arrival of spring.

It is marked by music, dance, and community gatherings.

short_summary: Kongali Bihu reflects simplicity and agricultural prayer.
description:
Kongali Bihu is observed during a lean agricultural period in Assam. Lamps are lit in fields and homes to pray for a good harvest.

The festival emphasizes hope, patience, and gratitude.

short_summary: Bhogali Bihu celebrates harvest and feasting.
description:
Bhogali Bihu marks the end of the harvesting season in Assam. It is celebrated with feasts, bonfires, and community gatherings.

The festival expresses joy, abundance, and togetherness.

short_summary: Ambubachi Mela celebrates fertility and nature.
description:
Ambubachi Mela is held at the Kamakhya Temple in Assam and is associated with the annual cycle of nature.

The festival draws devotees who believe it symbolizes fertility and renewal.

short_summary: Baishagu marks the New Year of the Bodo community.
description:
Baishagu is a spring festival celebrated by the Bodo community of Assam. It marks the beginning of the New Year and the agricultural cycle.

The festival is observed with music, dance, prayers, and respect for elders, symbolizing renewal and harmony with nature.

short_summary: Chhath Puja is dedicated to the worship of the Sun God.
description:
Chhath Puja is an ancient Hindu festival devoted to Surya, the Sun God. Devotees observe strict rituals, fasting, and offer prayers near water bodies.

The festival symbolizes gratitude, purity, and discipline.

short_summary: Bihula honors the Snake Goddess Manasa.
description:
Bihula is a folk festival associated with the worship of Goddess Manasa in Assam and neighboring regions.

It reflects local legends, devotion, and traditional storytelling practices.

short_summary: Bastar Dussehra is a tribal celebration distinct from classical Dussehra.
description:
Bastar Dussehra is a unique tribal festival celebrated in Chhattisgarh. Unlike the traditional Dussehra, it is dedicated to local deities and tribal customs.

The festival emphasizes community unity and ancestral worship.

short_summary: Phagun Madai is a moving tribal fair.
description:
Phagun Madai is a traveling festival celebrated by tribal communities of Chhattisgarh. It includes worship of local deities and cultural performances.

The festival strengthens social bonds among villages.

short_summary: Goa Carnival is a vibrant celebration before Lent.
description:
The Goa Carnival is a lively festival marked by parades, music, dance, and colorful costumes. It reflects Portuguese cultural influence.

The festival promotes joy, inclusiveness, and celebration of life.

short_summary: International Kite Festival celebrates the joy of kite flying.
description:
Held in Gujarat, the International Kite Festival attracts participants from around the world. The sky fills with colorful kites.

It marks the transition of the sun and festive togetherness.

short_summary: Gugga Naumi honors the folk deity Gugga Pir.
description:
Gugga Naumi is a folk festival celebrated in Haryana and surrounding regions. It is dedicated to Gugga Pir, associated with protection from snake bites.

The festival blends folklore, devotion, and regional traditions.

short_summary: Surajkund Mela showcases traditional crafts and culture.
description:
Surajkund Mela is an international crafts fair held annually in Haryana. It highlights handicrafts, music, dance, and cuisines from different regions.

The festival promotes cultural exchange and heritage preservation.

short_summary: Rann Utsav celebrates the culture of Kutch.
description:
Rann Utsav is a desert festival held in the White Rann of Kutch, Gujarat. It features folk music, dance, crafts, and desert experiences.

The festival showcases the rich heritage of the region.

short_summary: Bahu Mela is a religious fair held at the Bahu Fort temple.
description:
Bahu Mela is celebrated near the Bahu Fort temple dedicated to Goddess Kali. Devotees gather to offer prayers and participate in the fair.

The festival reflects local devotion, tradition, and community participation.

short_summary: Urs commemorates Sufi saints.
description:
Urs marks the death anniversary of a Sufi saint and is observed at dargahs. Devotees participate in prayers, qawwali, and charitable acts.

The festival symbolizes spiritual unity and devotion.

short_summary: Tulip Festival celebrates spring blossoms.
description:
The Tulip Festival is held in Srinagar to celebrate the blooming of tulips. Visitors enjoy floral displays and cultural programs.

The festival promotes tourism and appreciation of nature.

short_summary: Chhath Puja honors the Sun God with regional observances.
description:
Chhath Puja is observed at the state level with rituals dedicated to the Sun God. Devotees offer prayers near rivers and water bodies.

The festival emphasizes purity, gratitude, and discipline.

short_summary: Kambala is a traditional buffalo race festival.
description:
Kambala is a rural sport festival celebrated in coastal Karnataka. It involves buffalo races held in muddy fields.

The festival reflects agrarian culture and community spirit.

short_summary: Hampi Utsav celebrates the heritage of Hampi.
description:
Hampi Utsav is a cultural festival held at the historic site of Hampi. It includes dance, music, and heritage shows.

The festival highlights the glory of the Vijayanagara Empire.

short_summary: Onam is the harvest festival of Kerala.
description:
Onam celebrates the mythical return of King Mahabali. Homes are decorated with flower designs and cultural events are held.

The festival promotes equality, joy, and cultural pride.

short_summary: Vishu marks the New Year in Kerala.
description:
Vishu is celebrated as the New Year in Kerala. The day begins with Vishukkani, an auspicious arrangement viewed at dawn.

The festival symbolizes hope and prosperity.

short_summary: Thiruvathira honors Lord Shiva.
description:
Thiruvathira is observed mainly by women in Kerala and Tamil Nadu. It includes fasting, prayers, and the Thiruvathira dance.

The festival emphasizes devotion and marital harmony.

short_summary: Hemis Festival honors Guru Padmasambhava.
description:
Hemis Festival is celebrated at the Hemis Monastery in Ladakh. It features masked dances performed by monks.

The festival symbolizes victory of good over evil and spiritual wisdom.

short_summary: Sindhu Darshan celebrates the cultural importance of the Indus River.
description:
Sindhu Darshan is a festival observed in Ladakh to honor the Indus River as a symbol of harmony and unity. People from different parts of India gather to pay tribute to the river.

The festival promotes national integration and respect for nature.

short_summary: Lokrang Festival showcases folk arts and traditions.
description:
Lokrang Festival is a cultural celebration held in Madhya Pradesh that brings together folk artists from across India. It features traditional music, dance, crafts, and cuisine.

The festival helps preserve and promote indigenous cultural heritage.

short_summary: Khajuraho Dance Festival celebrates classical Indian dance.
description:
The Khajuraho Dance Festival is held near the historic Khajuraho temples and features performances of classical Indian dance forms.

The festival highlights the link between dance, spirituality, and heritage.

short_summary: Gudi Padwa marks the New Year in Maharashtra.
description:
Gudi Padwa is celebrated as the New Year by Maharashtrians. A decorated gudi is raised outside homes as a symbol of victory and prosperity.

The festival represents new beginnings and optimism.

short_summary: Naga Panchami honors the worship of serpents.
description:
Naga Panchami is a Hindu festival dedicated to the worship of serpent deities. Devotees offer milk and prayers to snake idols or images.

The festival reflects reverence for nature and ancient beliefs.

short_summary: Yaoshang is a spring festival of Manipur.
description:
Yaoshang is a vibrant festival celebrated in Manipur, similar to Holi. It combines sports, dance, and community celebrations.

The festival promotes youth participation and social harmony.

short_summary: Nongkrem Dance Festival is a thanksgiving ritual.
description:
The Nongkrem Dance Festival is celebrated by the Khasi tribe of Meghalaya. It is a thanksgiving ceremony seeking prosperity and peace.

Traditional dances and rituals form the core of the celebration.

short_summary: Chapchar Kut celebrates the arrival of spring.
description:
Chapchar Kut is a major festival of the Mizo community celebrated after forest clearing for cultivation.

It features folk dances, songs, and vibrant traditional attire.

short_summary: Mim Kut honors the harvest and departed souls.
description:
Mim Kut is a harvest festival of Mizoram associated with remembrance of ancestors. Food offerings are made in honor of the departed.

The festival emphasizes gratitude and remembrance.

short_summary: Pawl Kut marks the end of the harvest season.
description:
Pawl Kut is celebrated in Mizoram after the completion of the harvest. It is a joyful festival marked by feasting and community activities.

The festival reflects abundance and social unity.

short_summary: Hornbill Festival showcases the cultural heritage of Nagaland.
description:
The Hornbill Festival is a major cultural event in Nagaland that brings together the traditions of various Naga tribes. It features folk dances, music, crafts, and traditional sports.

The festival promotes unity, heritage preservation, and tourism.

short_summary: Sekrenyi is a purification festival of the Angami tribe.
description:
Sekrenyi is celebrated by the Angami tribe of Nagaland as a purification and renewal festival. It involves ritual bathing, feasting, and community celebrations.

The festival symbolizes cleansing, unity, and preparation for the new year.

short_summary: Rath Yatra celebrates the annual chariot procession of Lord Jagannath.
description:
Rath Yatra is a major Hindu festival associated with the Jagannath Temple in Puri. Deities are taken out in grand chariots and pulled by devotees.

The festival symbolizes devotion, equality, and collective participation.

short_summary: Raja Parba honors womanhood and the earth’s fertility.
description:
Raja Parba is a unique festival of Odisha that celebrates womanhood and the fertility of Mother Earth. It coincides with the onset of the monsoon.

The festival promotes respect for women and nature.

short_summary: Bhangra celebrates Punjabi harvest culture through dance.
description:
Bhangra is a vibrant folk dance festival associated with harvest celebrations in Punjab. It is performed with energetic movements and rhythmic beats.

The festival reflects joy, strength, and community spirit.

short_summary: Lohri marks the end of winter and the harvest season.
description:
Lohri is a popular winter festival in Punjab celebrated around a bonfire. People sing folk songs and offer harvest produce.

The festival symbolizes warmth, prosperity, and gratitude.

short_summary: Gangaur Festival honors Goddess Gauri.
description:
Gangaur is a colorful festival of Rajasthan dedicated to Goddess Gauri, symbolizing marital happiness and devotion.

Women participate in processions and prayers seeking prosperity.

short_summary: Losar marks the Tibetan New Year.
description:
Losar is celebrated by Tibetan Buddhist communities to mark the beginning of a new year. It involves prayers, rituals, and festive gatherings.

The festival signifies purification and renewal.

short_summary: Saga Dawa commemorates Buddha’s life events.
description:
Saga Dawa is a significant Buddhist festival marking the birth, enlightenment, and death of Lord Buddha. Acts of kindness and prayer are emphasized.

The festival promotes compassion and spiritual growth.

short_summary: Desert Festival celebrates Rajasthan’s desert culture.
description:
The Desert Festival is held in Jaisalmer and showcases Rajasthani folk music, dance, camel events, and cultural competitions.

It highlights the rich traditions of desert life.

short_summary: Aadi Perukku celebrates water resources and prosperity.
description:
Aadi Perukku is a Tamil festival celebrated during the month of Aadi to honor water bodies such as rivers, lakes, and reservoirs. It is especially significant along the banks of the Cauvery River.

The festival expresses gratitude for water, fertility, and agricultural prosperity.

short_summary: Thai Amavasai is observed for ancestral worship.
description:
Thai Amavasai is a significant new moon day in the Tamil month of Thai. People perform rituals in remembrance of ancestors, especially near rivers and seashores.

The observance reflects respect for lineage and ancestral blessings.

short_summary: Aadi Amavasai is dedicated to ancestor rituals.
description:
Aadi Amavasai is observed during the Tamil month of Aadi and is dedicated to performing rites for ancestors. Devotees gather at riverbanks and seashores for rituals.

The day emphasizes remembrance and spiritual continuity.

short_summary: Panguni Uthiram celebrates divine weddings.
description:
Panguni Uthiram is celebrated in Tamil Nadu to mark the celestial marriages of Hindu deities. It is especially important in Murugan and Shiva temples.

The festival symbolizes harmony, devotion, and divine union.

short_summary: Vaikasi Visakam celebrates the birth of Lord Murugan.
description:
Vaikasi Visakam marks the birth star of Lord Murugan and is celebrated with devotion in Murugan temples across Tamil Nadu.

The festival emphasizes courage, wisdom, and devotion.

short_summary: Thaipusam honors Lord Murugan through vows and devotion.
description:
Thaipusam is a major Tamil festival dedicated to Lord Murugan. Devotees undertake vows such as Kavadi Attam and offer prayers seeking blessings.

The festival represents discipline, faith, and sacrifice.

short_summary: Skanda Sashti commemorates Lord Murugan’s victory over evil.
description:
Skanda Sashti is a six-day festival celebrating Lord Murugan’s triumph over the demon Surapadman. It concludes with the Soorasamharam ritual.

The festival symbolizes courage, victory, and righteousness.

short_summary: Chithirai Festival celebrates the divine wedding in Madurai.
description:
Chithirai Festival is a grand temple festival held in Madurai, depicting the divine wedding of Goddess Meenakshi and Lord Sundareshwarar.

The festival showcases rich temple traditions and cultural heritage.

short_summary: Karthigai Deepam is the festival of lights in Tamil tradition.
description:
Karthigai Deepam is celebrated by lighting lamps in homes and temples across Tamil Nadu. The grand Deepam lit on the Annamalai hill at Tiruvannamalai is a major highlight.

The festival symbolizes spiritual light and knowledge.
